sorry, I should have provided this:
http://www.bossicard.com/projects/junit.php. It is a link to Vlad's junit
page.

-----Original Message-----
From: Chris Eppstein [mailto:ceppstein@...]
Sent: Tuesday, November 27, 2001 11:50 AM
To: 'junit@yahoogroups.com'
Subject: RE: [junit] Making JUnit more pluggable for add-ons


I, too, was interested to read this email and maybe I was out of line, but I
think the whole point of having different mailing lists is to let people
read the posts relevant to their interests. It makes sense that a lot of us
would take an interest in the direction of junit development since we're all
developers (and pretty good ones based on the high quality of the posts I
see here). But certainly there are plenty of readers who are not as
interested. Because of this, it is generally considered bad form to cross
post. I would suggest that those of us that are interested in development
should join the junit-devel list so this list can be the user list. Then
people can opt-in to the conversations that are interesting to them.
Anyways, I'll leave it to the moderators to define the scope of these lists.

Chris

P.S. On the topic at hand, I know that Vladimir Bossicard has implemented a
scheme that will let you register services with the junit architecture for
letting you extend it easily for custom reporting and what-not. I don't know
the current status of that effort though so perhaps he can comment?


-----Original Message-----
From: David Stagner [mailto:dstagner@...]
Sent: Tuesday, November 27, 2001 11:11 AM
To: junit@yahoogroups.com
Subject: Re: [junit] Making JUnit more pluggable for add-ons


Scott Stirling wrote:

> I'm glad he did.  But I guess this is the user list?  I thought it was the
> only JUnit list. Doh!


I'll second that i'm glad he cross-posted it.  I don't read the dev 
list, and probably wouldn't (i don't have enough time to read the lists 
that are higher priority as is).  I may not be actively involved in 
development, but i'm very pleased to see such a carefully thought out 
and well-written proposal on the regular list!  I think it's great to 
toss ideas for future development onto the general list, so long as they 
are nice and clear.  It's a good way to get feedback.

--
